reviewText: This game is...this game...the mechanics of the driving and all are actually pretty enjoyable, and the graphics are pretty decent too. The UI and voice acting leave a little to be desired, but I can live with that. But the missions, the missions, the missions are just unredeemably awful. If this had just been a normal racing game, I would have liked it, but the attempt at open-worldiness is half-baked at best and doesn't improve the game whatsoever. The missions are so finnicky that it's very easy to instantly end up in a position where it becomes unbeatable, and with the complete lack of checkpoints this means you're going to be doing a lot of restarting, doing the same boring stuff over and over and over again. Staying at just the right distance from another car isn't fun, at least as implemented here. And after playing this game for an hour, I didn't get into a single race, which was what I was looking for in the first place. I feel like this game has the makings of a really great low-budget Burnout, but they instead went for some police angle that just doesn't work at all, either thematically or mechanically.

reviewText:
If I had to compare Crash Time I would say a cross between Flatout and GTA driving controls. The driving scheme is interesting, and the damage portion is not as accurate or as hard hitting as Flatout, but does give satisfaction when you hit a car at a solid speed and the instant replay starts playing (one of the features of the game). The voice acting isn't as bad as everyone says (it's just the pauses between the voices that are weird).

The gameplay itself is not bad. The game involves a lot of running around, doing missions, knocking these guys out while protecting these guys that sort of bit. Some missions are ridiculously hard and require a lot of replays (some missions can get meticulous). What's interesting is you can flick on your emergency lights, put on hazard lights, put on your turn signals - so if you like driving by the law in GTA this may be for you.

Realistically speaking though the game provides its moments of fun and overall is playable and enjoyable. As for outstanding... not so much. It seems there are opportunities where it could have been, but it missed it's glory.

You still get a decent game to play though!

reviewText:
The first thing that you must keep in mind if you have purchased this game ( or got for free ) is that you didn't spend a whole lot of money for it. For this, you will be Thankful ; you do get what you pay for. Don't expect a Burnout Series game level of development and gameplay. If you want a ' quality ' game, be prepared to pay the premium and scroll past Crash Time 2.

The game is based on a German TV show called ' Alarm für Cobra 11 – Die Autobahnpolizei Ausfahrt ', a TV show that I cannot figure out as to whether or not is a serious crime drama or a German spoof take on the 80's series, Miami Vice. If you are from an English speaking country, the TV show that it is based on looks really really bad ( I did some youtube research by watching a couple of episodes to try and better understand what this game is based on )

Graphics :  I haven't seen a PC game since that late 90's that has such a short draw distance and pop in. You can actually see the grass grow as you drive by embankments. The developers must have heard ' Bloom ' and ' HDR  ' and thought ' you mean ' Glare ' as that is what you get. Glare then translates to making the screen bright white in some areas. The plus to this level of techincal wizardry is that you don't need an i7 and a pair of Titans to play this game. The specs required to play this game are from around 2003 i.e. if you are reading this review, your computer can run the game. Yes there are some slow downs, but in general, it's not a bad frame rate for a 2003 standard driving game. Unlicensed cars which are very obviously actual BMW, Mercedes, VW's, etc. The cars are not bad at all, hence why you can actually tell what they are based on ( or not badged as ). The city is well, German ( industrial, efficient and logically laid out but a little bland  ; mostly built in the last 70 years onwards due a disagreement with a couple of countries a number of years ago ).  Graphics wise, not the worst - not the best - kinda ' Eh ' if you can forgive the HDR ( or lack of ) and pop in that is.

Gameplay : Hmmm. You have a car and can drive around - really enough said. The ' handling ' is an arcade racer, not a sim. Don't expect fantastic drifts, just understeer and poor brakes. I tend to use the handbrake instead of the normal brakes for stopping. The nearest driving experience would be if CrazyTaxi had a love child with an early TOCA game. The story is as deep as a standard cup of water but hey, you either paid $0.99 or got this game for free right?

Voice acting : Voice acting needs a special mention all of it's own. You need to play the game to understand where I am coming from around this. I have NEVER heard such bad voice acting from ANY game, TV show, telemarketing scammer, etc. When I first heard the characters, it was quite amusing. As the game went on, it becomes, well a little bit creepy. Ever heard a 6 year old in a school play? Well it's a bit like that but spoken by a 40 plus year old guy.  Why really bad English accents? Why not German's speaking English? I think this would have worked better ( and they could have slipped in the word Squirrel for bonus points ) .... You have been warned.

Controls :  I have read some reviews on this game that say that the controls are difficult. I did not experience this problem as I plugged in my generic USB gamepad AKA PS2 copy and configured to suit a PS2 layout. You MUST use the D Pad to control the menu up and down then use the top button to select ( Triangle for PS2 ) and circle equivalent ( PS2 ) to go back. If you use the keyboard at any point on the menu, the game pad will be disabled. It's really not very hard to figure out though. To configure, enter the control lay out menu and set the control for the button of your choice ( press enter on the keyboard, then the button on the game pad that you want to use for that control ). For those that have configured a DOS / Windows 95/98 game pad, it's back to those days. Once configured, controls were responsive and worked as you want them to.

Conclusion :  Reading the above you are probably wondering why I am recommending this game? The fact remains that it is a very cheap ( or Free )  FULL game with graphics that exceed homebrew games. Buy it, but don't expect Burnout Paradise for $0.99c or Free. If you want Burnout Paradise, then don't be so cheap and buy it ( or wait for a Steam Sale 75% off ).

Note that support for the game was ditched after about a year from release, but likely not for the reason that Apple use to ditch support to sell you another product ( though we are upto Crash time 5 according to the interweb )

reviewText:
I recieved this for free from a site I found on reddit. While I of course like free games, I don't often also like playing them. As far as this title goes, I don't find anything special about this game, and in my opinion it is quite... uncomplete.

The graphics are decent at least, not great, but not bad either, and while they paid less attention to environment, cars are as shiny as they can be, which would make sense in a car game.

However the gameplay is where it takes a turn for the worse. The only storyline I've been able to gather is that you and a friend of yours are some sort of undercover cops who use a civilian car to catch. While there is no continuos gameplay, at least you have freeroam, and you can get random missions from the dispatch.

But let's see what the actual missions are about... well, chasing criminals, smashing their car until they come to a full stop. I have so many pet peeves when it comes to realism in this game that I can barely make myself write this review. Firstly, there are absolutely NO human animations. If the scenario makes your partner jump into a truck while you keep steady near it.... he just stays in the car, even though supposedly he is driving a truck now, even though he is still riding shotgun with you. Turning the wheel? No animation. Crashing recklessly in everything? No animations. The evil guy whos car you just totaled with nothing left other than the wireframe? No animation. What's more, you don't even arrest him. You just wreck his car (which takes a ridiculous ammount of bumping into) and then.. leave. And I guess he will just sit patiently idling (not like he has animations to begin with) in his carwreck until your fellow police officers arrive.

About the sound, not great either. The radio consists in a few metal instrumentals, which I can't say I dislike, but that's about it. No radio control, you always listen to the same tracks over. However that shouldn't be bugging you more than the total lack of talent in voiceacting. I'm not trying to bash the developer here. I didn't do my research, might as well be some guys in a basement, struggling to make their dream game but still... the voice acting is terrible. TERRIBLE.

All this being said, if you get the game from free from some random humblebudle-esque deal on the internet, go ahead and at least waste some time with this, however I would never recommend anyone actually paying money for.

reviewText:
Based on a long running german TV-series about two highway police officers, I cant say I ever watched the show but I'd say it is very loosely based on it.
Now, we all know games about movies tend to be usually bad, so what about a game about a TV-show? If your first thought was it must be worse than you'd be right.

In case you are a fan of police stories or racing then you should probably take a step away from this. If you just wanna crash into things and kill about 10 or 15 minutes while you wait for a better game to download then you might as well.

The cars and the damage models are the only thing remotely fun. As the damage model isnt only affecting your car visually but also your performance, the things they expect you to do, either will be fun or just frustrating.
Limiting the amount of damage your car can sustain or how much property damage you do are mission objectives that just utterly ruin it.
You'd think that it makes sense seeing how they are police officers but no, thats not the case in a lot of them. For instance: A girl gets kidnapped but as soon as your car takes more than 15% of damage the mission fails. Too bad girl, have fun with your kidnapper.

The awful mission design, horrendous voice acting and repetetive music is what will ultimately make this unenjoyable.

reviewText:
Where can i start with this game?

Well first off i got it for free so atleast im not annoyed that I payed the steep price of £6.99.
Secondly, Imagine everything you know and love about driving games like stuntman (which IMO this is a poor copy of), now forget it all. The game handles very poorly, from not being able to ue the analog stick in menus to the the car being sluggish to turn one second, to spinning 360 the next.
Continuing with controles, they are so random its not even amusing, (Y) is horn, (X) is siren (on, on silent, off), the right analog stick only has left and right in use and thats only for the respective indicators (im not even joking) and as far as i can tell, the bumpers do nothing at all (atleast in the tutorial anyway).

Interface wise the game is also quite poor, your speedo, map, mission objective and distance to target are all in seperate parts of the screen so you find yourself looking around at everything but the road. The speedo also has this odd feature of telling you what speed you need to hit ramps at, it will do this by taking up 1/4 of your screen and having a huge green mark and arrow at the speed you need to be, this speed is NOT optional, too slow you fall into a gap/dont make the jump, too fast and the game will send you flying into anything that it feels could be in your way.
There is also a replay cam that will replay what you did not 2 seconds ago (that seems about the extent og its record time) whenever it feels you've done something special, this is considered anything from a high speed overtake to a 45 degree turn, a 1080 aileron roll over a building or a 360 backflip over a roundabout? nah thats not replay worth (oh and your leads can get away while the replay is heppening).

Gameplay. The random spawn for cars is so borked that I swear i saw a family car with a caravon on it pull out of an industrial complex, and this wasnt a one off mistake, about 30 cars where queing to get out of a police testing area. The waypoints are another thing that are non-optional, miss one by a smidge and you will find yourself doing a 180 or slamming it into reverse while your lead gets away. Lastly that brings me to the persuit mechanics, it told me to attempt to stop the van with some light taps, instead I got infron of it and forced it to stop. Not good enough. Ok its traiing i can forgive that, so 5 taps it is, then I have to dissable the vehicle, so I flip it on its side with some fancy driving, nope, didnt fill the damage indicator so it de and respawns to carry on.

Overall this game was very poor, it looked ok back in 2010 when it was made im sure, but now its dated, jaded and needs to fade into the background.

~Round Up~

Story - unrated, I refused to play after the tutorial.
Graphics - 7 - There not the worst and I'm sure when it was released they did look good.
sound - 5 - forgetable OST with less than average voice acting topped with a siren that is all you can hear when its on. The only reason I didn't rate lower is becasue the crash sounds arn't that bad.
Gameplay - 3 - Poor controles with a bad HUD and strange mechanics.

Overall - 4 - It might have a good story and if your into games like stuntman you could get on with it but it just seems like a copy done wrong, if you like stuntman, break out the PS2 and play it, you'll have alot more fun, trust me. £6.99? I'd  still be anoyed if I'd paid £2.

I have over 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game.

One Hour Reviews #34 - Crash Time II

So the Oxford dictionary added janky to their list of words this year.

janky (adj.): of extremely poor or unreliable quality.

And it just so happens that janky sums up Crash Time 2 very nicely.

I start, like with many games, by trying out the Tutorial.  So I'm start with a mission where I have to pursuit and stop a car.  Okay, sound simple enough.  In fact, I very quickly pin the car against a fence, and render it completely immobile.  Oh wait, apparently the game didn't expect me to do that so soon, so instead of giving me credit for stopping the car, it disappears and then respawns.  Now I have to chase it down again.

Eventually I chase it down and this time I look long enough that the game rewarded me for it.  In the next part of the tutorial,  I have to chase the car again, except this time I have to ram it to do enough damage to stop it.  So I start ramming the car, and eventually I make the car flip over.  Awesome, I win, right?  Oh wait, no, instead of getting credit for stopping the car, the game just makes the car respawn.  Apparently it wants me to keep ramming the car.  Apparently this game equates thinking outside the box with cheating.

So after ramming my way to victory, next I'm on a mission where it tells me to hit the Action Button" to launch a remote control drone.  It doesn't tell me which button on the controller that is

voteText: and not those pesky X or A buttons.\n\nSo now that I've figured out how to hit the action button

reviewText: Not worth your time. Doesn't live up to the name. It is not about crashing or damaging cars, it's about conducting boring routine tasks as a german police officer. First and foremost, the car models are quite well done, with excellent graphics for the time it came out. Apparently that is where the studio spent all their time and money. The game honestly feels like a graphical showpiece for car modeling. Besides the cars, the environments look blocky and bad. The gameplay also suffers. The worst offender is the car driving, as I can't remember driving mechanics so poor. Your small boring generic sedan, which is basically the only car you drive during the game, handles like a boat. Turns are taken terribly, and breaking seems to take forever to slow down. There is no handbreak or way to take quick turns, which means turning basically means slowing down to a complete stop then slowly turning. Backing up doesn't work either. Once you've stopped you press break and it changes you to reverse, then you need to let off the button and press it again to start backing up. There is no way to look at controls in game. I had no idea what anything did. I tried looking for a handbrake, and there seemed to be 2 different ones, but once didn't turn you faster, it only flung your forward at an angle for some reason when you were slowing down. There is no way to look behind you, which you actually need to do in the game, so I have no idea why they wouldn't include it. You have to use this tiny unhelpful rearview mirror. Then there is the gameplay. The single player makes no sense and isn't untuitive. There is a case, single race, and patrol at multiple different locations - tabs. Apparently you just select a patrol with a flag and then drive around and wait to get a call, which makes no sense for a single player. The voice acting may be the worst and cheesiest I've ever heard. Missions have multiple parts, but if you fail 2/3 in you have to start from the beginning for no reason. This is easy because if you get spun around or accidentally hit the wrong turn, as is common with the terrible direction indicator on your small map, or you get stuck behind the tiny railing that you can't get through (logic?) and you are following someone, you will fall behind the certain distance. Then there are the parts you have to break a car to win. You are a cop but you have no gadgets or guns to help you, all you can do is crash into cars........sounds like the plan of no cop ever. Destroying vehicles takes forever because damage modeling makes no sense, and you only do tiny damage at a time. I flipped a car over 3 times within 30 seconds and he would just drive off with no damage to the top or side of his car. It never makes sense how the cars get damaged. So you have to destroy a car but it literally takes 7 minutes of you following it around hitting it, having no idea how far you are in destroying it, because it never changes in performance. Then there are missions that have you drive to certain spots to check things out, but instead of 3-4 spots, the game has you go to FOURTEEN spots, which should take about 12-15 min, for no reason but to inflate length and give you busy work. That isn't fun because the random german city is boring and generic looking, with nothing interesting to look at. There is really nothing to make this game worth playing. Good vehicle graphics though, even if they are super un-interesting to use or look at. 4/10.

tl;dr buy it on sale
An open world game about European Police. Well, A European city with british coppers. With stock sounds, laughable voice acting and a physics engine that doesn't quite understand mass you'll definately have a strange, yet somewhat enjoyable experience playing this game.

The voice acting in this game is quite bad. However if you pair that with the terrible jokes slipped in, it actually becomes
quite humourous, for the wrong reasons of course. The sound effects are stock sounds and the soundtrack is mediocre but expected for this type of game. You can put your own music in the game which will help you play for a little bit longer. Although the process of putting your music in could be tedious if you're not familiar with file explorers.
The graphics are actually quite good. There are great lighting and shadow effects and the textures are high resolution. The models of the vehicles are quite reasonable and there is a lot of detail in the damage of the cars. Realistic or not, it definately brings the game up.
Now, talking of the damage of the cars, there is definately a lot of detail put in and the damage is local to where you hit. Parts of the vehicle will hang off and debris will come from the vehicles. The vehicles also stop break down if you sustain too much damage to the engine area, though this can be annoying.
However, the vehicles do not crumple and wheels fly off at almost all high speed crashes. NPC vehicles explode with little damage, with their explosions causing no damage to surrounding vehicles. Also if you're travelling at ~90mph or above, most vehicles will just be smashed out of the way with little effect on your speed, which brings me on to the physics engine.
Vehicles that are part of the missions are better at taking collisions. But the physics are inconsistent. You can spin out a vehicle with a slight tap, yet if you shunt them from behind they experience next to no loss of control. This is quite annoying when you have to take down a vehicle as you have to wait for them to turn a corner so you can smash them in the side at high speed if you want to do any damage.
The handling of the vehicles isn't the best. But it's not quite the worst. It's easy to slalom and weave through traffic but if you want to turn a corner at high speed, you're gonna have a bad time. You need to slow down to near stopping point if you want to turn the corner without completely missing it or smashing into a wall and have a wheel fly off.

Is it worth the money?
I bought it for 69p (~$1), and I'm cetain I  haven't  wasted my money. The normal price is around £7 (~$11) and I would be reluctant pay that for the game. But I'm a bit of a cheapskate. If I payed around £3.50 (~$5.55), I wouldn't be dissappointed.

Should you buy it?
I'd say  yes!  Even with all these bad points, I still like the game. It's almost as if you don't notice it when playing; you never really expected much from it anyway. I could play this for an hour or so burst before I would get bored of it. Not to say I wouldn't come back to it. The  humour  in the voice acting and custom soundtrack should keep you going through the missions. It's not a bad game really.

Crash Time 2 is an odd mix, but very enjoyable as a driving simulator for cruising around in the depicted german town. I'll preface by saying that I haven't played more than a few missions, but have spent hours cruising around.

You get the brief impression from loading the game that it may have been re-branded from a more conventional german road driving simulator, but it almost liberates the player from taking their time on the road too seriously. The voice actors continue this first impression, causing the gamer to question exactly what subliminal german propaganda is being pumped through their speakers - because clearly, it can't be that superficial..

Yet, for all of its faults, there are plenty of great qualities.
1. The graphics are still nice and shiny on newer directX releases, and it holds up well over the span of 5 years - a virtual eternity, so to speak.
2. The almost apathetic mixture of citizens and police driving around makes for some catastrophic crashes while business as usual goes on around them.
3. The driving itself, while not exactly precise in terms of the on-the-road handling physics, is pretty fun. It maintains a good balance between lively handling and classic arcade driving. The chases are a little easy if we're honest, but the crashes make it worthwhile.
4. The comedy gold. If you start to look at the voice acting less as an actual attempt to create a dramatic environment and more of a strange video game cameo of mystery science theater 3000 post-translation, you'll be able to appreciate the rich social commentary presented between the lines. Bonus points for trying to drive with no front wheels, just a stream of sparks originating from your low-speed collision.
5. The damage contest. While it's not a great idea when you're racing, one of the best parts of the game is seeing just how much property damage you can rack up before The engine exploded."..

I found Crash Time II to be a rather enjoyable car chase/racing game that allows you to speed through a European city and wreck havoc, while no one seems to mind.  The trick to really enjoying this game, however, is that you have to get past the frustrating first mission.  You know how most games give you easy tasks at the beginning of the game, and just about the time you think you got the hang of it, the difficulty ramps up until you begin to feel like a failure?  Crash Time II does just the opposite.

The first mission requires you to perform a rather tricky maneuver, followed by extensive car chase in which you need to disable the car you are pursuing by ramming it over and over until it's an immobile pile of metal.  This is more difficult than it sounds, especially when you are new to the game.  In fact, it took me over three hours to complete the level.  After that, however, the game became much easier, with the next several missions being timed tasks, races, or chases that only require pinning your target instead of destroying them.  Yes, the game has several other frustrating missions that require multiple attempts, but by this time your skill is better and they don’t take as long or seem as daunting.

I played this game both with a controller and with a keyboard and mouse.  Personally, I have no preference and found both methods adequate.

Helpful Tips to make the game more fun and reduce frustration:

1.  Play in easy mode.  The chase missions are hard enough -- a simple wrong turn can allow an enemy to escape in an instant.

2.  Read the manual.  At least scan it. I spent a lot of time driving around doing nothing early in the game until I read the manual and figured out why missions weren't triggering.

3.  When you are required to completely disable another vehicle, avoid pinning it for too long.  Back off and let it get going before ramming it again.  What the game neglects to tell you is that all the criminals have graduated from Hogwarts and, when pinned, will suddenly disappear and reappear elsewhere, sometimes far enough away that they can escape before you even have time to turn your vehicle around.

Finally, the voice acting is brilliant!  No, I didn’t say it was good, well written or well acted.  Just brilliant.

I may be late to the review party, but I finally got around to finishing this game. I've owned it for probably over a year. But, as this is on Steam, there are bound to be more gamers giving it a go. So, here is my review on Crash Time 2: Burning Wheels.
When I first picked it up, I really wanted to like it.
Now, don't get me wrong, I do not hate it; I just don't like it...much.

I will dive right in with the Pros-v-Cons.
Pros:

+ Graphics:  Despite a little too much bloom effect on some of the models, and the occasional clipping, the overall graphic quality of the game was enjoyable.
+ Control:  There is a catch (see Cons). I use an XBox 360 controller for all racers, and the control is fairly good in this with the occasional understeer issues aside. For me, keyboards just don't make good racers. The on/off switch controls just won't cut it in my opinion. Kudos to those who can pull it off with good results.

+ Comedic Value:  The translation from German to English is laughable at times. And the English voice acting is, in a word, atrocious. I would love to hear feedback from German speaking gamers on whether or not the original actors/script were any better.

+ Soundtrack:  Great rockin' soundtrack and the ability to add your own tracks made for an enjoyable time.

+ Damage System:  I loved how the car fell apart and stopped performing accordingly.

Cons:

- But that Camera:  Here's the control catch. My first issue was the camera. Too often, I found myself going around a winding road corner and smacking right into another car that I could not see from the camera scheme offered. Or worse yet, a sneaky little outcropping in the wall, strategically placed to catch you unaware and throw you off your line. Both things that you could see in the first person camera if not for the lack of left/right control. The 3rd person high camera was what I would typically gravitate toward, but you still could not see what was coming around the corner. I realize some driving line planning is in order here, but being able to use the right joystick for camera control left and right would have been ideal. Nobody drives with there head and eyes glued straight forward.  Unless, of course they are staring at a cell phone (Don't even get me started on that).

- Stick to the Mission. What Mission???:  At times, finding missions was harder than it should have been. I've read, in several online posts, that you had to be in a particular car, in a particular place, for HQ to contact you. However, in many missions, I would start off in said particular vehicle only to have to drive back and switch to another vehicle to continue the mission. It shouldn't be that difficult.

I actually enjoyed playing this game once I figured out the no mission issue.  I always read reviews to know what I'm getting into before purchasing a game.  Occasionally, I will steer clear of one because of them.  However, ultimately, enjoyment really depends on each individual gamer.

Would I pay sticker price for this game?   Well, THAT is what I read reviews for.
As much as I love to support the creators as much as possible, I am on a limited budget so the games I pay full price for need to be really worth it.  So, the answer to the question, is no.

That being said, I will most likely be trying Crash Time 3: Highway Nights" soon. And I hope the other 2 installments will be released in the U.S. as well.  Why?  Because most people tend to get better as they learn more and develop their craft.  I hope the same rings true for Synetic.  Everyone has to start somewhere.  Give "Crash Time 2: Burning Wheels. " a try. It's no Need for Speed
